page.title: 01ALL ABOUT CRANLEIGH
page.content: Our village, popularly supposed to be the largest village in England, lies between Guildford and Horsham in the Lower Weald. Just north of the village the land rises to the wooded slopes of the Greensand Ridge. Although not mentioned in the Domesday Book the tiny hamlet of "Craneley" formed part of the Manor of Shere owned by Editha, wife of Edward the Confessor. It was named after the cranes, a popular table bird in Norman times which were bred on the many ponds. Until the 1960's the village retained its quiet rural atmosphere but the development of several large housing estates caused a sudden rise in the population. The spelling was changed to Cranleigh at the request of the GPO to avoid confusion with Crawley.
